bibl.title: Despatches from United States Consuls in Gaboon, 1856-1888 T-466

text.body:
Gaboon Nov. 16th 1866
We ], Rear Admiral, Commander in Chief of the Naval Division of the West Coast of Africa; Chief Commandant of the Settlements of the Gold Coast and the Gaboon.
By reason of the new commercial regime which is about to be established in the waters of the Gaboon.
Have decreed and do *unclear
Oct. 1st. The provisions of the Commercial Code relative to the keeping of accounts and to declarations of Bankeeper will be put in force from January 1st 1867. Commencing on the same date with all individuals entering into commercial transactions and who make such their habitual profession will be held to be traders
Oct 2nd Every person, French, foreigner, or trader within the radius of the French profession at Gaboon or who may intrude to follow it must make
his declaration to the Commandant "Particular" and to the "Ordemiation" officiating as Director of the Interior, between this day and the 20th of December 1866, and later, ten days before commencing business. The Ordemnation is charged with keeping a register of the said declarations.
Oct. 3 Each merchant established at Gaboon or who wishes to establish himself there must provide himself within the delays and periods you said.
1stly With a day-book in which must be entered day by day all his business transactions his recount current and general lu all that he may have recieved or paid on any account whatever. This day-book must insure show month by month the amount dibursed for house expenses.
2ndly With a Letter book into which month be expired all the letters sent by the merchant concerning his business affairs.
3rdly With a stock book in which must be entend each year the Inventory of his property both goods and efforts and of the account current. There books must be posted according to date without blanks, hiatus or hansfermers to margin. They must be preserved by the Merchant for ten years.
The Day-book and Stock book must be paged, paragraphed and signed between the 10th and 25th of December of each year by the Commandant Particular who officials at Gaboon as Justice of the Peace and as Mayor. This Magistrate will keep a register of the accomplish must of this formality.
Finally every trader must present the letters which he may receive concerning his bill received and bills payable and other business operations.
Oct. 4th denouncing with January 1st 1867. Bankeeply will be declared by the Commandant Particulaier upon the advice of the Commercial Commit the established by Seerne of Bason Circulat Commandant Supenor dated March 28th 1862, approved by *unclear* despatch of Feburary 9th 1863 (Colonial+Bureau)
Oct. 5th of the Commercial Committee in verifying the Books of a Merchant should conceive doubts as to the nature of the givin to natives, it may appoint on of its members to clear up the matter. The Commandant Particulier will purside at the debates which may aim from these ingains* and shall decide in the first instance upon the validty of the debt according to the lactude allowed him by the local ordiances or dierus; the night of petition before the beundts of Jr. Louis or Govermaning always open.
Oct 6th At the end of the year the Commercial Committee meeting in the absence of a Chamber of Commerce shall draw up a repost in duplicate, to be laid before us upon the importance of the transactions which have been carried on in the waters of the Gaboon.
Oct 7th The Commandant Particulier and the Commandant officiating as Director of the Interior are intrusted each in that which concerns have with the execution of the present decre which shall be registered whenever it may be necessary and brought to the knowledge of the merchants and trader, and of all the Gaboon chiefs in relation with us.
Oct.8th The tariff of duties on the entry of merchandise and the shipment of produce, already sent for the association of the Excellency the Minister of Marine and the Colonies will be notified by as later to the public.
Oct 9th All provisions enactments contrary to the present decree are and shall remain resealed.
The Rear Admiral Commmander in Chief Commmandant Supenor of th French settlement to the Gold Coast and at Gaboon.
Signed, V.A. de Jongle
